selected.extractionSummary: This peer-reviewed paper proposes an axiomatic framework for mathematical scale theory using cyclic group theory and cyclic order relations. It formalizes scales as cyclic embeddings from a diatonic tone set into a chromatic tone set, unifying previous work on maximally even scales, well-formed scales, and Myhill's property. The paper argues that cross-cultural scale commonalities (5–7 tones, moderate interval sizes, asymmetry) arise from psychological and perceptual constraints. It establishes formal correspondences between cyclic ordered sets, generalized interval systems, and regular group actions as three equivalent viewpoints on pitch-class systems.

claims.text: The concept of a musical scale as a collection of pitch classes is universal throughout the world, and the notion of the octave and octave equivalence are found universal across cultures.

citations.quote: The concept of a musical scale as a collection of pitch classes is universal throughout the world, even though these scales exhibit great variety and differences. While the notion of the octave and octave equivalence are found universal...

claims.text: Cross-culturally, scales typically contain between five and seven tones, with intervals between adjacent scale tones ranging between one and three semitones, and asymmetric scales being more common than symmetric ones.

citations.quote: commonalities include the amount of tones in a scale often ranging between five and seven, intervals between adjacent scale tones being between one and three semitones in size, and asymmetric scales being more common than symmetric ones

claims.text: The typical number of scale tones (5–7) relates to the amount of distinct pitches that a human can reliably keep track of, a psychologically-grounded constraint.

citations.quote: The typical number of scale tones relates to the amount of distinct pitches that a human can reliably keep track of

claims.text: The prevalence of moderately small intervals between consecutive scale degrees results from constraints that large intervals are more difficult to sing and too-small intervals are hard to distinguish by the human ear.

citations.quote: The prevalence of moderately small intervals between consecutive scale degrees may result from constraints that large intervals are more difficult to sing and too small intervals are hard to distinguish by the human ear

claims.text: Scale asymmetry enables the creation of complex tonal structures by making positions in the scale easy to perceive and remember, and there is mathematically only one maximally asymmetric scale (up to isomorphism) for each given tone material and scale size.

citations.quote: The most remarkable commonality is the asymmetry that enables the creation of complex tonal structures by making the positions in the scale easy to perceive and to remember... there is only one – up to isomorphism unique – 'maximally asymmetric' scale for each tone material and given scale size

claims.text: The diatonic C major scale (C, D, E, F, G, A, B) is a maximally even, non-symmetric scale with a trivial cyclic automorphism group, while the octatonic scale is also maximally even but has four proper rotational symmetries.

citations.quote: The diatonic scale does not have proper (non-trivial) rotational symmetries whereas the hexatonic and the octatonic scale have three and four proper rotational symmetries, respectively. In contrast to the hexatonic scale, the octatonic scale and the diatonic scale are maximally even.

claims.text: In 12-tone equal temperament, the chromatic scale has cardinality 12, and the diatonic scale has cardinality 7; intervals between two scale tones can be measured in two ways: specific (chromatic) size and generic (diatonic) size.

citations.quote: The specific or chromatic size of an interval between two (black) scale tones is one plus the number of white and black vertices strictly in between them in clockwise direction. The generic or diatonic size of an interval between two scale tones is one plus the number of only black tones strictly in between them in clockwise direction.

claims.text: Both pitch-class collections and rhythms are formally cyclic structures, making the mathematical framework for scales directly applicable to rhythmic patterns (e.g., talas in Indian music).

citations.quote: both pitch-class collections and rhythms are cyclic structures, the former in the pitch class dimension and the latter with respect to bars in western music or talas in Indian music. In this analogy, a rhythmic pattern is a sequence of note onsets drawn from a metrical grid just as a western scale is a sequence of pitch classes drawn from a chromatic universe

claims.text: The diminished-seventh chord is totally symmetric (every tone has the same relations to all other tones), whereas the octatonic scale, despite appearing symmetric, is not totally symmetric.

citations.quote: the former is totally symmetric – that is every tone has the same relations to all other tones – while the latter is not

details.description: Enharmonically identified chromatic universe; chromatic scale modeled as integers modulo 12

compositionParameters.value: C major scale: C, D, E, F, G, A, B (diatonic size 7, chromatic size 12)

details.modeledAs: cyclic embedding from Z_7 into Z_12

compositionParameters.value: Octatonic scale (half-step/whole-step diminished): 8 tones, 4-fold rotational symmetry, maximally even
Hexatonic scale: 6 tones, 3-fold rotational symmetry, not maximally even
Interval size range for adjacent scale degrees: 1–3 semitones (cross-cultural norm)

openQuestions: Can the axiomatic cyclic-order framework be extended to non-octave-equivalent tuning systems (e.g., Bohlen-Pierce) or microtonal scales?
What psychological mechanisms specifically underlie the preference for 5–7 tone scales—is it purely working memory capacity, or are there additional auditory processing constraints?
How do 'more sophisticated quantifications of asymmetry' beyond maximal asymmetry correlate with cross-cultural aesthetic preferences or learnability of scales?
Can the formal equivalence between rhythmic and pitch-class cyclic structures be exploited to generate novel compositional mappings between rhythmic patterns and scales?
To what extent does the mathematical uniqueness of the maximally asymmetric scale explain the prevalence of the diatonic scale across unrelated musical traditions?
How does the automorphism group structure of a scale relate to perceptual ratings of tonal stability or memorability?
Can well-formedness and Myhill's property be meaningfully defined for continuous (non-equal-tempered) pitch spaces, and what would that imply for just intonation scales?

selected.sourceTitle: Full article: Gauge models of musical forces
selected.extractionSummary: This paper develops a gauge-theoretic model of tonal attraction in music cognition, applying concepts from quantum field theory (specifically SU(2) gauge symmetry) to explain both static and dynamic tonal attraction. The model unifies two earlier approaches: a phase model (U(1) symmetry) and a spatial deformation model (SO(2) symmetry). Tonal attraction is modeled using wave functions along the circle of fifths, with a polynomial spatial deformation function that produces excellent agreement with Krumhansl & Kessler's (1982) empirical tonal hierarchy data. The framework treats musical forces (gravity, magnetism, inertia) not as metaphors but as structurally real phenomena arising from symmetry-breaking, analogous to gauge forces in physics.

claims.text: In Krumhansl & Kessler's (1982) probe-tone experiments, the tonic pitch received the highest tonal attraction rating, followed by the pitches completing the tonic triad (third and fifth), then the remaining scale degrees, and finally chromatic non-scale tones.

citations.label: Krumhansl & Kessler 1982 hierarchy finding
citations.quote: The results of this experiment clearly show a kind of hierarchy: the tonic pitch received the highest rating, followed by the pitches completing the tonic triad (third and fifth), then followed by the remaining scale degrees, and finally followed by the chromatic, non-scale tones.

claims.text: Lerdahl's hierarchical model of tonal attraction produces predictions in excellent agreement with experimental data for major keys, but shows significant deviations for minor keys.

citations.label: Lerdahl model performance
citations.quote: The predictions of the hierarchical model are in excellent agreement with the experimental data in the case of major keys. In case of minor keys (based on the natural or harmonic minor scale), however, there are significant deviations.

claims.text: The spatial deformation model using a fourth-order polynomial deformation function on the circle of fifths produces excellent agreement with static tonal attraction data from Krumhansl & Kessler (1982).

citations.label: Deformation model validation
citations.quote: With this deformation function, beim Graben and Blutner (2019) found excellent agreement with the static attraction data of Krumhansl and Kessler (1982).

claims.text: Western tonal music in equal temperament has a fundamental transposition symmetry described by the cyclic group Z_12, generated by intervals of minor seconds (1 semitone), major sevenths (11 semitones), perfect fifths (7 semitones), and perfect fourths (5 semitones).

citations.label: Z12 group generators
citations.quote: In the numerical representation of the cyclic group Z12 there are four generators represented by the numbers 1,11,7, and 5. Hence, 1 (one minor second upward) and 11 (one minor second downward) generate the sequence of semitones. In addition, the elements 5 and 7 enumerate the group elements in successive fourths or fifths, respectively, thereby generating the circle of fifths.

claims.text: Tonal hierarchies that privilege certain notes over others appear to be a near-universal feature of music across cultures, serving a cognitive function as landmarks for melodic memory and interpretation.

citations.label: Cross-cultural tonal hierarchy
citations.quote: Although it is normally applied only to Western music, the word 'tonal' is appropriate for any music that recognizes a hierarchy that privileges notes to different degrees. That's true of the music of most cultures.

claims.text: Dynamic tonal attraction (harmonic resolution) cannot be fully understood without reference to static tonal attraction (tonal hierarchy); the two are interdependent.

citations.label: Static-dynamic interdependence
citations.quote: dynamic attraction phenomena cannot be understood without their static counterparts. The models of Lerdahl and Krumhansl (2007) realize this idea in an indirect way by requiring static attraction as one constituent of their dynamic attraction algorithm.

claims.text: The tritone (at π on the circle of fifths, e.g., G♭ relative to C) receives maximal spatial deformation in the model, while the tonic receives no deformation, reflecting the tritone's maximal instability in tonal hierarchy.

citations.label: Tritone deformation maximum
citations.quote: A consequence of this choice is that the tonic (at 0) should not be deformed while the tritone (at π) receives maximal deformation.

claims.text: Three musical forces — gravity (tendency of notes heard as 'above a stable platform' to descend), magnetism (tendency of unstable notes to move toward the nearest stable pitch, growing stronger with proximity), and inertia (tendency of a melodic pattern to continue in the same direction) — can be modeled as conceptual metaphors structuring musical cognition.

citations.label: Larson & VanHandel 2005 musical forces
citations.quote: Musical gravity is the tendency (attributed by a listener) of a note (heard as 'above a stable platform') to descend (to that platform) […]. Musical magnetism is the tendency (attributed by a listener) of an unstable note to move to the closest stable pitch, a tendency that grows stronger as we get closer to that goal. […] Musical inertia is the tendency (attributed by a listener) of a pattern of motion to continue in the same fashion.

claims.text: In the force-free case, the qubit model, scalar Schrödinger wave function model, and spinor Pauli wave function model all yield identical predictions for tonal attraction.

citations.label: Model equivalence in force-free case
citations.quote: For the force-free case, the three quantum models discussed above, namely the qubit model, the scalar Schrödinger wave function model and the spinor Pauli wave function model yield identical predictions for static and dynamic tonal attraction.

details.description: Adjacent notes have identical frequency ratios; transposition operations form cyclic group Z_12

details.anchoringStrength: counted as number of levels shared (A–D)

details.generatorInterval: perfect fifth (7 semitones) or perfect fourth (5 semitones)
details.mapping: tone j maps to x = jπ/6

details.source: Experimental stimuli from dynamic attraction probe-tone study

compositionParameters.value: Tonic vector Ψ₀ = (1, 0) representing C in qubit Hilbert space

details.basicRotationAngle: π/12 radians per semitone on circle of fifths

openQuestions: Can the SU(2) gauge model be extended to explain tonal attraction in non-Western tuning systems or microtonal music where Z_12 symmetry does not apply?
Why does the Lerdahl hierarchical model perform well for major keys but show significant deviations for minor keys — and can the gauge model resolve this discrepancy?
What is the physical or cognitive interpretation of the gauge field itself in the musical context — what does it correspond to neurologically or psychoacoustically?
Can the spatial deformation function (4th-order polynomial) be derived from first principles or perceptual data, rather than chosen as a convenient interpolation?
How does the model's treatment of dynamic tonal attraction scale to longer musical sequences, not just single probe tones following a chord?
Is there empirical evidence that the 'magnetic interaction' term in the decomposed Hamiltonian corresponds to a measurable perceptual or neural phenomenon?
How would the model handle quartal harmony, atonal music, or modal music where the tonic-dominant axis is weakened or absent?
Does the cross-cultural universality of tonal hierarchies imply that the Z_12 cyclic group structure is a perceptual universal, or is it culturally contingent?
Can the gauge-theoretic framework be used generatively — i.e., to compose music that maximizes or shapes tonal attraction profiles in specific ways?
How does octave equivalence assumption (collapsing to 12 pitch classes) affect the model's accuracy, and could a model incorporating octave register improve predictions?

selected.sourceTitle: Full article: Discovering distorted repeating patterns in polyphonic music through longest increasing subsequences
selected.extractionSummary: This peer-reviewed paper presents a novel algorithm for discovering repeating patterns in polyphonic symbolic music under transposition and time-warp invariances. The algorithm uses an onset-time-pair representation to reduce the pattern discovery problem to instances of the classical longest increasing subsequence (LIS) problem, achieving O(n² log n) time complexity where n is the number of notes. The approach handles distortions common in live performance transcriptions (tempo variation, timing inaccuracy) better than prior methods like SIA/SIATEC, which only tolerate sporadic note-level distortions. The paper also presents windowed variants that restrict onset-time differences for more musically meaningful results, and notes that time-scaled (as opposed to time-warped) pattern discovery remains a significantly harder open problem.

claims.text: Real music is almost inevitably polyphonic, meaning that a multitude of parallel tones may sound at any time, making musical pattern discovery significantly more complex than text or linear structure pattern matching.

citations.label: motivation for polyphonic approach
citations.quote: As real music is almost inevitably polyphonic, meaning that a multitude of parallel tones may sound at any time, the corresponding musical task is much more complex. An exhaustive search through all possible sequences of tones would shortly lead to a combinatorial explosion.

claims.text: Identical musical patterns may appear in different keys and/or at different written tempos, and these systematic distortions can be handled by examining relative rather than absolute pitch and duration values (transposition and time-scale invariance).

citations.label: systematic distortion handling
citations.quote: Distortions may be systematic, for instance, identical patterns may appear in different musical key and/or in different written tempo. Such distortions are easy to handle by looking at relative values instead of absolute values: in pitch at the pitch difference, in duration at the quotient between corresponding durations.

claims.text: The SIA and SIATEC algorithms for maximal repeating pattern discovery under transposition and time-shifting invariances work in O(n² log n) and O(n³) time respectively, but fail to find musically meaningful repetitions in live performance transcriptions because they cannot tolerate systematic tempo variation.

citations.label: SIA/SIATEC limitation
citations.quote: The SIA and SIATEC algorithms are tolerant to distortion in the time dimension only to a some extent: if a note is out of time, it is simply discarded. This works rather nicely when only some sporadic notes are distorted. However, when the input is a transcription of a live performance, for instance, the method omits totally the vast majority of the musically meaningful repetitions.

claims.text: The new repeating pattern discovery algorithm under transposition and time-warp invariances works in O(n² log n) time and is more suitable for live performance transcriptions where tempo varies and onset times are rarely accurate.

citations.label: algorithm complexity claim
citations.quote: We have described a new repeating pattern discovery algorithm that can be used to find both exact and time-warped repetitions in O(n² log n) time where n is the number of notes in a musical work.

citations.label: motivation for time-warp
citations.quote: in live performances, the tempo varies and onset times are rarely accurate making the time-warp invariance desirable for the onset times.

claims.text: Finding time-scaled repetitions (where the ratio of corresponding durations is a constant α) is significantly harder algorithmically than finding time-warped repetitions; the best known algorithms for the time-scaled pattern matching problem require quadratic time, and no efficient algorithm exists for time-scaled repeating pattern discovery.

citations.label: time-scaled vs time-warped difficulty
citations.quote: it seems that finding only time-scaled repetitions is much harder than finding time-warped repetitions

citations.label: quadratic time lower bound for time-scaled
citations.quote: the best known algorithms for the easier time-scaled pattern matching problem () already require quadratic time

claims.text: Allowing stronger invariances in pattern matching algorithms increases the risk of false-positive repetitions, necessitating a post-processing phase to discard extraneous matches.

citations.label: invariance-precision tradeoff
citations.quote: the more the algorithms allow distortions, the more they also generate false-positive repetitions. Therefore, a post-processing phase is often needed to discard extraneous ones.

claims.text: A geometric piano-roll representation of music, where each note is a 2D point with onset time on the x-axis and pitch on the y-axis, supports transposition and time-shift invariance and provides a useful foundation for polyphonic pattern matching algorithms.

citations.label: geometric representation origin
citations.quote: Meredith, Lemström, and Wiggins (2002) suggested a piano-roll-like geometric representation of music where each note is represented by a point in the plane. In this representation, the horizontal location (x-axis) gives the onset time for a musical event and the vertical location (y-axis) its pitch level.

claims.text: The paper uses Western equal-tempered polyphonic music as its domain, and by working in the symbolic music domain it explicitly avoids the hard problem of fundamental frequency estimation from polyphonic audio.

citations.label: scope and domain
citations.quote: In this paper, we consider the problem of finding repeating patterns in Western equal tempered polyphonic music... By using a symbolic representation we avoid the very challenging problem of the fundamental frequency estimation of a general polyphonic audio music case.

details.notes: Explicitly stated as the tuning system for which the algorithm is designed

openQuestions: Can an efficient (sub-quadratic) algorithm be developed for time-scaled repeating pattern discovery in polyphonic music, given that the current best approaches require quadratic time?
How can musically interesting patterns be automatically filtered from the large set of mathematically valid repeating patterns detected by time-warped algorithms?
Is there a time-warped equivalent of the SIATEC algorithm that finds all occurrences of each discovered maximal pattern (without relying on translation vectors)?
How well does the geometric point-set / onset-time-pair representation transfer to audio-domain polyphonic music when combined with fundamental frequency estimation?
What window parameters (w, d) are musically optimal for different genres or performance styles when using the windowed variant of the algorithm?
Can the algorithm be extended to handle harmonic/timbral features beyond pitch and onset time, enabling richer invariance combinations?
How does performance scale in practice for very large musical datasets (e.g., full orchestral scores with thousands of simultaneous notes)?
Could this framework be applied to non-Western tuning systems, or does the equal-temperament assumption limit its applicability?

selected.extractionSummary: Meantone temperaments are tuning systems built from sequences of tempered fifths (slightly narrower than the just 3:2 ratio) designed to bring major or minor thirds closer to just intonation ratios of 5:4 or 6:5 respectively. Quarter-comma meantone, the most historically prominent variant, was dominant from the early 16th to early 18th centuries and produces pure just major thirds (5:4) by tempering each fifth by 1/4 of a syntonic comma. Twelve-tone equal temperament (12-TET) can be understood as approximately 1/11-syntonic-comma meantone, producing major thirds that are wide by about 13 cents compared to just intonation. Several equal temperament systems (19, 31, 53 TET, etc.) serve as close approximations to specific meantone variants. The whole tone in meantone systems is the geometric mean of the just major tone (9:8) and minor tone (10:9), hence the name 'meantone.'

claims.text: A perfect fifth in just intonation has a frequency ratio of exactly 3:2.

citations.label: Definition of just perfect fifth
citations.quote: rather than using perfect fifths, consisting of frequency ratios of value 3:2

claims.text: A just major third has a frequency ratio of 5:4 and a just minor third has a ratio of 6:5.

citations.label: Just third ratios
citations.quote: in order to bring the major or minor thirds closer to the just intonation ratio of 5:4 or 6:5, respectively

claims.text: In 12-TET, each semitone equals one-twelfth of an octave, with frequency ratio 2^(1/12):1, and the perfect fifth has ratio 2^(7/12):1.

citations.label: 12-TET definition
citations.quote: Twelve-tone equal temperament (12 TET) is obtained by making all semitones the same size, with each equal to one-twelfth of an octave; i.e. with ratios 12√2 : 1

citations.label: 12-TET fifth ratio
citations.quote: a frequency ratio of 2^{7/12}:1

claims.text: 12-TET narrows the perfect fifth by approximately 2 cents (1/12 of a Pythagorean comma) relative to Pythagorean tuning, and produces major thirds that are wide by about 13 cents relative to the just 5:4 ratio.

citations.label: 12-TET fifth deviation
citations.quote: Relative to Pythagorean tuning, it narrows the perfect fifths by about 2 cents or 1/12 of a Pythagorean comma

citations.label: 12-TET major third deviation
citations.quote: This produces major thirds that are wide by about 13 cents, or 1/8 of a semitone

claims.text: 12-TET is almost exactly equivalent to 1/11-syntonic-comma meantone tuning, with a fifth tempering of 1.955 cents vs. 1.95512 cents.

citations.label: 12-TET as meantone approximation
citations.quote: Twelve-tone equal temperament is almost exactly the same as 1/11 syntonic comma meantone tuning (1.955 cents vs. 1.95512)

claims.text: In quarter-comma meantone, four ascending tempered fifths (C–G–D–A–E) produce a just major third C–E with ratio 5:4, which is one syntonic comma (~22 cents) narrower than the Pythagorean major third.

citations.label: Quarter-comma meantone major third construction
citations.quote: Four ascending fifths (as C G D A E) tempered by 1/4 comma (and then lowered by two octaves) produce a just major third (CE) (with ratio 5:4), which is one syntonic comma (or about 22 cents) narrower than the Pythagorean third that would result from four perfect fifths

claims.text: The syntonic comma is the ratio 81/80, representing the difference between the Pythagorean major third (81/64) and the just major third (5/4).

citations.label: Syntonic comma defined
citations.quote: the ratio of the Pythagorean third 81/64 to the just major third 5/4

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone has a residual gap (diesis) between F# and Gb of 125/128, or approximately −41.06 cents — nearly twice the size of the Pythagorean comma and in the opposite direction.

citations.label: Quarter-comma meantone diesis
citations.quote: there is a residual gap in quarter-comma meantone tuning between the last of the upper sequence of six fifths and the last of the lower sequence; e.g. between F♯ and G♭ if the starting point is chosen as C, which, adjusted for the octave, are in the ratio of 125/128 or −41.06 cents

claims.text: In third-comma meantone, three descending tempered fifths produce a just minor third of ratio 6:5, and this system is closely approximated by 19-TET.

citations.label: Third-comma meantone minor third
citations.quote: three descending fifths (such as A D G C) produce a just minor third (AC) of ratio 6/5

citations.label: 19-TET approximation
citations.quote: Third-comma meantone can be very well approximated by a division of the octave into 19 equal steps

claims.text: The quarter-comma meantone whole tone is the geometric mean of the just major tone (9:8) and just minor tone (10:9), equal to √(5/4) ≈ 1.11803, or approximately 193.157 cents.

citations.label: Meantone whole tone as geometric mean
citations.quote: √(10/9 · 9/8) = √(5/4) = 1.1180340, equivalent to 193.157 cents: the quarter-comma whole-tone size

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone can be closely approximated by 31-TET, which closes the spiral of fifths into a circle.

citations.label: 31-TET approximation of quarter-comma meantone
citations.quote: Quarter-comma meantone can be well approximated by a division of the octave into 31 equal steps

citations.label: 31-TET closing the spiral
citations.quote: Slightly tempered versions of the two systems that do close into a much larger circle of fifths are 31 TET for meantone

claims.text: 53-TET almost perfectly approximates both Pythagorean tuning and 5-limit just intonation.

citations.label: 53-TET as near-perfect Pythagorean/JI approximation
citations.quote: 53 TET almost perfectly fits both Pythagorean tuning and 5 limit just intonation, with a few 7 limit and 11 limit intervals

claims.text: A whole number of just perfect fifths can never sum to a whole number of octaves, because log₂(3) is irrational.

citations.label: Fundamental impossibility of closing a circle of just fifths
citations.quote: A whole number of just perfect fifths will never add up to a whole number of octaves, because log₂3 is an irrational number

claims.text: Wolf intervals in keyboard instruments are artifacts of using insufficient keys rather than inherent properties of the tuning system itself.

citations.label: Wolf interval origin
citations.quote: Wolf intervals are not inherent to a complete tuning system, rather they are an artifact of inadequate keyboards that do not have enough keys for all of the in-tune notes used in any given piece

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone was in common use from the early 16th century until the early 18th century, after which 12-TET came into general use; it persisted for church organs well into the 19th century.

citations.label: Historical usage timeline
citations.quote: It was commonly used from the early 16th century till the early 18th, after which twelve-tone equal temperament eventually came into general use. For church organs and some other keyboard purposes, it continued to be used well into the 19th century

claims.text: A tuner can achieve quarter-comma meantone by ear near middle C (~264 Hz) by listening for beats at approximately 1 Hz when comparing a reference perfect fifth to the tempered note.

citations.label: Practical quarter-comma tuning by ear
citations.quote: Since this amounts to about 0.3% of the frequency which, near middle C (~264 Hz), is about one hertz, they could do it by using perfect fifths as a reference and adjusting the tempered note to produce beats at this rate

claims.text: For a tuning to qualify as meantone, its fifth must be between 685+5/7 cents and 700 cents in size.

citations.label: Meantone fifth size range
citations.quote: For a tuning to be meantone, its fifth must be between 685+5/7 and 700¢ in size

claims.text: Historically used meantone temperaments occupy a narrow range of fifth sizes, approximately 695 to 699 cents.

citations.label: Historical meantone fifth range
citations.quote: Historically, commonly used meantone temperaments, discussed below, occupy a narrow portion of this tuning continuum, with fifths ranging from approximately 695 to 699 cents

claims.text: Tempering the partials of synthesizer tones to match non-12-TET tunings can restore harmonic coherence in tuning systems far from quarter-comma meantone.

citations.label: Partial tempering for microtonal synthesis
citations.quote: This can be overcome by tempering the partials to match the tuning, which is possible, however, only on electronic synthesizers

details.context: Reference frequency used in historical meantone tuning by ear; 1/4 comma ≈ 1 Hz beat rate near this pitch

details.definition: Difference between Pythagorean major third (81/64) and just major third (5/4)

details.location: Between F# and Gb in a 12-note keyboard tuned from C

details.derivation: Geometric mean of major tone (9:8) and minor tone (10:9)

compositionParameters.value: Just major tone = 9:8 (≈ 203.91 cents), just minor tone = 10:9 (≈ 182.40 cents)

openQuestions: How perceptible is the 13-cent wide major third in 12-TET to trained vs. untrained listeners, and does context (harmonic vs. melodic) affect this perception?
What are the compositional implications of using 31-TET (near-perfect quarter-comma meantone) for contemporary music, given its availability on electronic instruments?
How does partial tempering on synthesizers (matching overtone series to non-12-TET tunings) affect timbral perception and psychoacoustic consonance?
Can the historical ear-tuning method (listening for ~1 Hz beats near middle C at ~264 Hz) be reliably taught and reproduced today, and how does it compare in accuracy to electronic tuning?
What is the perceptual threshold at which the wolf interval (−41 cents in quarter-comma meantone) becomes unacceptable in different musical contexts?
Why did 12-TET prevail over meantone in the early 18th century despite meantone's superior thirds — was it primarily practical (keyboard design, modulation needs) or aesthetic?
How do composers like Ligeti and Adams who specifically demand meantone in their scores integrate the tuning system into their harmonic language?
Is there a psychoacoustic advantage to tuning systems where the whole tone is the exact geometric mean of the major and minor tones, or is this purely a mathematical elegance?
How closely does 53-TET approximate 7-limit and 11-limit just intervals beyond the 5-limit, making it potentially useful for extended just intonation work?

selected.sourceTitle: Full article: Exploring annotations for musical pattern discovery gathered with digital annotation tools
selected.extractionSummary: This peer-reviewed study investigates inter-annotator agreement in musical pattern annotation using two digital tools (ANOMIC and PAF) applied to six monophonic excerpts from Bach, Beethoven, Haydn, and Mozart. The research finds significant disagreement between annotators even among musical experts, with agreement varying by educational background, tool interface, and musical excerpt. Feature-based analysis across 33 musical pattern attributes reveals that tool choice and annotator background both influence which patterns are identified, with 23 of 33 features showing significant differences between the two datasets. The study highlights the fundamental problem that there is no single comprehensive definition of a musical pattern, making ground-truth annotation for algorithm evaluation inherently ambiguous. Results suggest that richer, multi-annotator datasets are needed to properly evaluate automatic pattern discovery algorithms.

claims.text: There is no clear single comprehensive definition of what constitutes a musical pattern or even repetition, making single-reference annotations problematic for algorithm evaluation.

citations.label: core claim
citations.quote: the ambiguity of musical structures and the different conceptualisations of the notion of patterns make the use of reference data relying on only a very small number of experts rather problematic: there is no clear single comprehensive definition of what constitutes a pattern, or even repetition

claims.text: Not all recurring sequences are perceived as patterns by listeners; perception depends on the structural position of the pattern, the listener's moment-to-moment perception, and the listener's musical background or music-theoretic education.

citations.label: perceptual claim
citations.quote: not all recurring sequences are perceived as patterns by the listener, as this depends on the structural position of the pattern (), the listener's moment-to-moment perception, and other influencing factors such as the listener's musical background or music theoretic education

claims.text: Inter-annotator agreement for musical pattern annotations is generally low, with ANOMIC musician annotators averaging an F-score of 0.61 and non-musicians averaging 0.63 at a 5-crotchet threshold, dropping to 0.47 and 0.38 respectively at a 1-crotchet threshold.

citations.label: agreement scores at 5-crotchet threshold
citations.quote: the average inter-annotator agreement for the musician group is 0.61, and 0.63 for non-musicians

citations.label: agreement scores at 1-crotchet threshold
citations.quote: The agreement values become much smaller among the ANOMIC non-musicians (0.38) and the musicians (0.47), for the crotchet threshold of 1

claims.text: Annotators from different musical study programmes (musicology, music theory/composition, music pedagogy) show different inter-annotator agreement patterns, suggesting that academic music training background influences pattern perception.

selected.sourceTitle: How Horses Make Two Sounds at Once
selected.extractionSummary: A study published in Current Biology reveals that horse whinnies consist of two simultaneously produced sounds: low-frequency vocal fold vibrations (~200 Hz) and high-frequency laryngeal whistles (>1,000 Hz). Researchers confirmed this dual mechanism by blowing helium through excised horse larynxes — helium raised the pitch of the whistle (which depends on airstream turbulence and sound speed) while leaving the vocal fold vibration frequency unchanged. Horses are the first large mammal known to produce laryngeal whistles, and the only animal known to combine them simultaneously with vocal fold vibrations. The two frequency components are hypothesized to convey distinct emotional messages, suggesting the whinny evolved as a multi-channel communication signal.

selected.sourceTitle: Full article: Towards a mathematical foundation for music theory and composition: a theory of structure
selected.extractionSummary: This peer-reviewed paper proposes rigorous mathematical foundations for music theory and composition using topos theory and presheaf categories, extending Guerino Mazzola's framework from 'The Topos of Music.' The author argues that existing mathematical music theory (including pitch-class set theory) suffers from ad-hoc constructions and implicit definitions, and proposes a unified theory of 'structure' governed by three principles: comprehensive comprehension, explicit encoding, and minimal ontological commitments. The framework uses functor categories and presheaves to encode musical phenomena—including pitch spaces, duration spaces, groups, gestures, and synthesizer parameter spaces—within a single ontological system. A key motivation is enabling the synthesis of algebraically and topologically defined musical entities (formulae and gestures) without an ontological divide between them. The paper also identifies an open problem: formulating an analog to Mazzola's denotators within the new framework.

claims.text: Pitch-class set theory, despite being a mathematical approach, relies on intuitive notions of sets and assembles advanced constructions in an ad-hoc manner, lacking rigorous mathematical foundations.

citations.label: critique of pitch-class set theory foundations
citations.quote: In pitch-class set theory, for example, reliance on intuitive notions of sets is common, and more advanced constructions are frequently assembled in an ad-hoc manner.

claims.text: Classifying chords using group-theoretic invariance (transposition, inversion) provides a more scientifically agreeable and systematic basis than subjective criteria such as 'dissonant,' 'consonant,' or 'pretty.'

citations.label: group theory vs. subjective chord classification
citations.quote: In contrast to this more rigorous approach of classifying chords based on invariance with respect to group transformations, classifying chords based on subjective criteria—such as e.g. 'dissonant,' 'consonant,' 'pretty,' etc.—lacks a solid foundation agreeable to a community.

claims.text: Forte's pitch-class set theory posits ordered and unordered sets as fundamentally distinct ontological categories declared 'by fiat' rather than deriving them systematically from a foundational framework, which is epistemologically problematic.

citations.label: Forte's ontological over-commitment
citations.quote: The lack of a foundational system necessitated the positing of two fundamentally distinct ontological categories: ordered and unordered sets. However, non-naive set theory (such as ZFC) would have entailed fewer ontological commitments, requiring only a commitment to the concept of a set.

claims.text: A unified mathematical ontology for music theory enables comparison and synthesis of diverse musical objects—from twelve-tone serial works to Gagaku music—without requiring alterations to the foundational system.

citations.label: universality claim for proposed framework
citations.quote: Such a system would allow the theorizing of diverse musical genres, such as e.g. the works of Milton Babbitt and Gagaku music, without requiring alterations to the foundational ontology.

claims.text: Mazzola's algebraic (module-presheaf) and topological (gesture) frameworks represent an ontological divide between 'formulaic' and 'gestural' musical realities, which this paper proposes to overcome through a unified structure theory.

citations.label: Mazzola's algebraic/gestural ontological divide
citations.quote: The ontological distinction between these two theories lies in their treatment of algebraic versus topological entities, respectively. For Mazzola, this distinction marked a significant insight, highlighting the differences between formulaic and gestural realities in music.

claims.text: Product structures in a presheaf category can encode the Cartesian product of musically distinct parameter spaces (e.g., pitch space and duration space), yielding composite structures with pitch-duration pairs.

citations.label: pitch-duration product structure
citations.quote: In the realm of music, a structure might define a pitch space while another defines a duration space; their product structure would therefore contain both pitch and duration information.

claims.text: Function structures in a presheaf category can encode sequences of group elements indexed by a totally ordered set, which is musically interpretable as an ordered sequence of harmonic objects.

citations.label: function structure as musical sequence
citations.quote: If S is a total order and T is a group, a mapping [from S to T] expresses a sequence of group elements from T, where the sequence is indexed by the elements of S.

claims.text: Topos theory provides a unified and systematic approach to encoding musical phenomena, offering a rigorous foundation that supports product, coproduct, power, and function operations on musical structures.

citations.label: topos framework capabilities
citations.quote: The presheaf framework offers essential operations such as product, coproduct, power, and function structures, facilitated by the topos properties inherent in the presheaf category.
